"[W]e’re all losing the ability to engage in what I view as the pinnacle of human interaction: sitting around with friends and talking shit. "Clean code can be slower." Sure. If you wrote it in assembler, it'd be even faster! Readable code is easier to maintain, faster to change, and less bug-prone, as it's harder to break if you understand it better. And if you have bugs in your code, they will impact its performance. But also, not every code needs to be super fast, fast enough is often enough. Moreover, it's not either-or, if needed, you can optimize things while sacrificing some readability. title: BUG: inconsistency between prepared and unprepared polygon contains predicate · Issue #740 · libgeos/geos

last_post.content:
GEOS is pretty darn robust, but there's an interesting class of failures that are the root of more than one of the extant issues.

When evaluating predicates (true/false tests on geometry relationships) and full DE9IM relationships, JTS/GEOS will perform noding on the inputs before evaluating the relationship between them.

This results in a sort of "heisenberg uncertainty principle" of geometry predicates. The act of evaluating them changes them slightly.

https://github.com/libgeos/geos/issues/740#issuecomment-1325776721
